We need to generate diffences between succesive numbers. And then check if they are all increasing, or all decreasing. And if the increase/decrease is between 1 and 3 inclusive.

title: Advent of Code 2024
text:
The example
First write a fuction, that, given a vector of numerics, calculates the change from element to element. It then checks if they are all increasing or decreasing. And if the absolute change is larger than 0 or smaller than 4.

check <- function(x){
  x <- c(x[-1], NA) - x
  x <- x[!is.na(x)]
  res1 <- all(sign(x) == 1) | all(sign(x) == -1) # all increasing or decreasing
  res2 <- all(abs(x) < 4 & abs(x) > 0)
  res1 & res2
}

The tricky thing was to construct the vector with the changes from element to element. And it was not that tricky.
Rather than constructing the example manually, I saved it to a txt-file.
I read it, convert it to at tibble, split it on white spaces, and coerce it to numeric. All in a list-column:

example <- readLines("data/day-02-example.txt") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>% 
  mutate(vectors = str_split(value, " ")) %>% 
  mutate(vectors = map( vectors, as.numeric))

Now we can map the check-function on the list-column, unnest it, and sum all the logical values:

example %>% 
  transmute(check = map(vectors, check)) %>% 
  unnest(check) %>% 
  summarise(answer = sum(check))

# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  answer
   <int>
1      2



The actual task
Having checked that the example returns the correct answer, we run it on the input. First read in the data:

task <- readLines("data/day-02-input.txt") %>% as_tibble() %>% 
  mutate(vectors = str_split(value, " ")) %>% 
  mutate(vectors = map( vectors, as.numeric))

And now we do the exact same operations:

task %>% 
  transmute(check = map(vectors, check)) %>% 
  unnest(check) %>% 
  summarise(answer = sum(check))

# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  answer
   <int>
1    479




Part 2

The example
We need to remove the first element in the vector, and check it. And to remove the second element and check that, etc.
We write a new function, which by default returns FALSE, but if one of the point-deletions of an element lead the vector to pass the check-function, it returns TRUE:

dampener <- function(x){
  res <- FALSE
  for(i in 1:length(x)){
    if(check(x[-i])) res <- TRUE
  }  
  res
}

We run that on the example:

example %>% 
  transmute(check = map(vectors, dampener)) %>% 
  unnest(check) %>% 
  summarise(answer = sum(check))

# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  answer
   <int>
1      4




The actual task
We got the correct answer, and now run the same code on the task-data:

task %>%   
  transmute(check = map(vectors, dampener)) %>% 
  unnest(check) %>% 
  summarise(answer = sum(check))

# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  answer
   <int>
1    531

title: Advent of Code 2017
text:
Having a sequence of digits, one digit with the next (or, if the digit is the last, the first digit in the sequence). The digits that are the same as the next digit, are added together. Do that for a very large number.



1122 produces a sum of 3 (1 + 2) because the first digit (1) matches the second digit and the third digit (2) matches the fourth digit.
1111 produces 4 because each digit (all 1) matches the next.
1234 produces 0 because no digit matches the next.
91212129 produces 9 because the only digit that matches the next one is the last digit, 9.

Construct the test-cases:

example <- c("1122", "1111", "1234", "91212129")

Why a character vector? The input for the actual task might technically be a number. But it is so huge that we do not want to handle it as such.
We split the input, and convert to a numeric vector. Next that vector is shiftet to the right, placing the last value as the first, the first as the second etc. Then we compare those two vectors, and use that as a boolean index to the values.

captcha <- function(input){
  input <- str_split_1(input, "") |> as.numeric()
  input_shifted <- c(input[length(input)], input[2:length(input)-1])
  sum(input[input == input_shifted])
}

Testning:

captcha(example[4])

[1] 9


It works.



Read in the input:

input <- readLines("data/day-01-input.txt")

Use it as input to the function:

captcha(input)

[1] 1171


First star!




Next we need to shift the vector even more. 50% in fact. This requires a new captcha function:

next_captcha <- function(input){
    input <- str_split_1(input, "") |> as.numeric()
    len <- length(input)
    input_shifted <- c(input[(len/2+1):len], input[1:(len/2)])
    sum(input[input == input_shifted])
  }




1212 produces 6: the list contains 4 items, and all four digits match the digit 2 items ahead.
1221 produces 0, because every comparison is between a 1 and a 2.
123425 produces 4, because both 2s match each other, but no other digit has a match.
123123 produces 12.
12131415 produces 4.

Setting up example data:

example <- c("1212", "1221", "123425", "123123", "12131415")

Testing:

next_captcha(example[2])

[1] 0






next_captcha(input)

[1] 1024


Done ğŸ„

title: Advent of Code 2015
text:
The total area of the box - we need to get the three pairwise products of width, length and height. The sum of that should be multiplied by 2. And the smallest area should be added.
Two tests:

test_1 <- c(2,3,4)
test_2 <- c(1,1,10)

We can get all the pairwise products using combn:

(x <- combn(test_1, 2, prod))

[1]  6  8 12


The sum should be doubled, and the smallest value added:

2*sum(x) + min(x)

[1] 58


That appears to be correct. Lets make a function:

area <- function(x){
  x <- combn(x, 2, prod)
  2*sum(x) + min(x)
}

It also returns the correct result for test_2:

area(test_2)

[1] 43

title: Advent of Code 2015
Advent of Code 2015
text:
We have some input to an MD5 hash algorithm.
It consist of some padding, which is provide, preprended to a number in decimal.
We now need to find the lowest positive integer, with no leading zeroes, that results in a hash that starts with at least five zeroes.
We use a library to get access to an MD5 function:
library(openssl)

Linking to: OpenSSL 3.4.1 11 Feb 2025
And test that
test_hash <- md5("abcdef609043")
Starts with â€œ00000â€:
startsWith(md5("abcdef609043"), "00000")

[1] TRUE
Cool, the md5 function we get from openssl actually works as expected.
We write a function, that checks if a given integer, x, padded with pad, returns a result starting with n zeroes:
solution <- function(x, pad = "abcdef", n = 5){
  startsWith(md5(paste0(pad,x)), paste0(rep(0,n), collapse = ""))
}
The input we are given for padding is:
pad <- "iwrupvqb"
And we can now find the answer by bruteforcing:
res <- FALSE
i <- 0
while(!res){
  res <- solution(i, pad = pad, n = 5 )
  if(res){
    answer <- i}
  i <- i+1
}
answer
But we are not going to show it here.

title: Advent of Code 2015
text:
Handling an infinitely large matrix? Nope!
Tibble with coordinates? Yes!
Based on the last positino we can add a row, based on the drunken-elfo-instructions. If we want to know how many presents have been delivered to a given positon, we count all the occurences of that position in the tibble.
As always, because I speak tidy:
library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.5.1


Warning: package 'tibble' was built under R version 4.5.1


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.5.1


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.5.1


â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4     âœ” readr     2.1.5
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.1
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.2     âœ” tibble    3.3.0
âœ” lubridate 1.9.4     âœ” tidyr     1.3.1
âœ” purrr     1.1.0     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
We make a tibble, which is not actually a grid, but a tidy grid:
grid <- tibble(X = 0, Y = 0)
X is east/west, Y is north/south. If we go north, we add 1 to the Y-value of the current position, -1 if going south. And do not change the X-value. If we go east, we add 1 to the X-value. You get the point.
We have an awful lot of instructions, and make a named list with what should happen with the (X,Y) values of the current position, when we update it.
scheme <- list("^" = c(X = 0, Y = 1),
               "v" = c(X = 0, Y = -1),
               "<" = c(X = -1, Y = 0),
               ">" = c(X = 1, Y = 0))
We write a function to do that - it makes mapping easier:
coord <- function(x){
  scheme[[x]]
}
It takes input, and returns the vector with the corresponding changes in X and Y.
But we do not actually need to update anything. We just need to register all the changes, and can find a given position by adding up all the changes - we do that by taking the cumulative sum.
We have some examples:
test <- "^v^v^v^v^v"
We split it
test %>% str_split_1("") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>%   
  transmute(coord = map(value, coord)) %>% 
  unnest_wider(coord)

# A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
       X     Y
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1     0     1
 2     0    -1
 3     0     1
 4     0    -1
 5     0     1
 6     0    -1
 7     0     1
 8     0    -1
 9     0     1
10     0    -1
We are missing the first postion, (0,0). So let us add that:
rbind(grid, test %>% 
  str_split_1("") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>%   
  transmute(coord = map(value, coord)) %>% 
  unnest_wider(coord)
 )

# A tibble: 11 Ã— 2
       X     Y
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1     0     0
 2     0     1
 3     0    -1
 4     0     1
 5     0    -1
 6     0     1
 7     0    -1
 8     0     1
 9     0    -1
10     0     1
11     0    -1
This is the start position, and all changes. So now we take the cumulative sums:
rbind(grid, test %>% 
  str_split_1("") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>%   
  transmute(coord = map(value, coord)) %>% 
  unnest_wider(coord)
 ) %>% 
  transmute(x = cumsum(X), y = cumsum(Y)) 

# A tibble: 11 Ã— 2
       x     y
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1     0     0
 2     0     1
 3     0     0
 4     0     1
 5     0     0
 6     0     1
 7     0     0
 8     0     1
 9     0     0
10     0     1
11     0     0
We now have the grid-coordinates, and simply needs to count how many times each coordinate has been visited. The number of rows in that result is the number of individual coordinates - and that is the answer we are looking for:
rbind(grid, test %>% 
  str_split_1("") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>%   
  transmute(coord = map(value, coord)) %>% 
  unnest_wider(coord)
 ) %>% 
  transmute(x = cumsum(X), y = cumsum(Y)) %>% 
  count(x, y) %>% nrow()

[1] 2
That gives us the answer we are told is correct for the test.
Now we simply have to do the same for the input file:
input <- readLines("../aoc2015/data/day-03-input.txt") 

Warning in readLines("../aoc2015/data/day-03-input.txt"): incomplete final line
found on '../aoc2015/data/day-03-input.txt'

rbind(grid, input %>% 
  str_split_1("") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>%   
  transmute(coord = map(value, coord)) %>% 
  unnest_wider(coord)
 ) %>% 
  transmute(x = cumsum(X), y = cumsum(Y)) %>% 
  count(x, y) %>% nrow()

[1] 2592
Nice.

title: Advent of Code 2015
text:
Task 2
Robo-santa and Santa are going to share the distribution. Elfo is still drunk.
We need to split up the input in two. Odd-numbered instructions go to Santa, even-numbered to Robo-santa.
Read in data, add rownumbers, and split into two:

input <- input %>% 
  str_split_1("") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>% 
  mutate(r_num = 1:nrow(.))

input_santa <- input %>% 
  filter(r_num %% 2 == 1)
input_robo_santa <- input %>% 
  filter(r_num %% 2 != 1)

Repeat the exercise from above for the two versions of Santa.

santa_grid <- rbind(grid, input_santa %>% 
                          transmute(coord = map(value, coord)) %>% 
                          unnest_wider(coord)) %>% 
                          transmute(x = cumsum(X), 
                                    y = cumsum(Y)) 

robo_grid <- rbind(grid, input_robo_santa %>% 
                          transmute(coord = map(value, coord)) %>% 
                          unnest_wider(coord)) %>% 
                          transmute(x = cumsum(X), 
                                    y = cumsum(Y)) 

We then combine the two grids:

rbind(santa_grid, robo_grid) %>% 
  count(x, y) %>% 
  nrow()

[1] 2360


Done.

We make a lookup table. Given a position and an instruction, what is the new position?

 4, 7, 7, 8,

  matrix(nrow = 9, byrow = T,

lut

pos U D L R

  2 2 5 1 3
  3 3 6 2 3
  4 1 7 4 5
  5 2 8 4 6
  6 3 9 5 6
  7 4 7 7 8
  8 5 8 7 9
  9 6 9 8 9

new_pos <- function(pos, instruction){
  lut[pos, instruction]
}

Construct the instruction set:

input <- c("ULL", "RRDDD", "LURDL", "UUUUD")

Split and save in list:

input <-   str_split(input, "")

Write a function that loops through the length of the instruction set, and in an inner loop loops through the instructions in each element.

answer <- numeric()
pos <- 5
for(i in 1:length(input)){
  for(j in input[[i]]){
    pos <- new_pos(pos, j)
  }
answer[i] <- pos
}

title: Advent of Code 2024
text:
Task 2
Now it gets more complicated. There are instructions in the text. â€œdo()â€ in the text indicates that all following multiplications should be executed. â€œdonâ€™t()â€ that all following multiplications should not.
We need to identify those as well.
Start by reading in the data again, because assigning data back into the original is a bad ideaâ€¦

input <- readLines("data/day-03-input.txt") 

Now we convert it to a tibble like before, but now we also extract the two different types of instructions:

input <- input %>% as_tibble() %>% 
  transmute(instructions = str_extract_all(value, "mul\\(\\d{1,3}\\,\\d{1,3}\\)|do\\(\\)|don\\'t\\(\\)", simplify = F) ) %>% 
  unnest(instructions)
input

# A tibble: 713 Ã— 1
   instructions
   <chr>       
 1 mul(234,359)
 2 mul(260,344)
 3 mul(87,298) 
 4 mul(407,173)
 5 mul(763,519)
 6 mul(258,409)
 7 mul(703,155)
 8 mul(423,685)
 9 mul(647,758)
10 mul(595,333)
# â„¹ 703 more rows


We canâ€™t see it here, but there are doâ€™s and donâ€™ts in the instructions column.
Those needs to be separated out:

input <- input %>%
  mutate(instruction = case_when(
                              str_detect(instructions, "do") ~ instructions,
                              .default = NA))
input

   instructions instruction
   <chr>        <chr>

Again - they are thereâ€¦
When we encounter a â€œdo()â€ in the instruction column, all following multiplications should be executed, until we encounter a â€œdonâ€™t()â€. So we fill down. We still have som NAâ€™s at the top of the tibble, we replace those with â€œdo()â€

input <- input  %>% 
  fill(instruction, .direction="down") %>% 
  replace_na(list(instruction = "do()")) 
input

We are only interested in the multiplicaitons with â€œdo()â€ in the instruction column - lets filter to get them:

input <- input %>% 
  filter(instruction != "don't()") %>% 
  filter(str_starts(instructions, "m"))

We also need to get rid of those control-words in the instructions column.
And now the rest is done as before:

input %>% 
  mutate(instructions = str_remove_all(instructions, "mul\\(|\\)")) %>% 
  separate_wider_delim(instructions, delim = ",", names = c("factor_1", "factor_2")) %>% 
  mutate(across(everything(), as.numeric)) %>% 
  transmute(products = factor_1 * factor_2) %>% 
  summarise(answer = sum(products))
